qas.question: What are SNES game cartridges officially called in the US?
What are SNES game cartridges officially called in Japan?
How much data space can an SNES cartridge use?
What were the largest SNES games?

answers.text: Tales of Phantasia and Star Ocean

qas.question: How much data do the smallest SNES games use?

plausible_answers.text: The cartridge media of the console

qas.question: What is referred to as Cassette in Western regions?

plausible_answers.text: The cartridge media of the console

qas.question: What is referred to as Game Pak in Japan?
How much ROM data do Talesof Phantasia and Star Ocean have as the smallest games released?
What mappings do most Game Pak support in Japan?
How many Mbit of FastROM are contained in games from Latin America?

context: <b5_0><b6_0>The cartridge media of the console<b6_0/><b5_0/> is officially referred to as <a0_0>Game Pak<a0_0/> in most Western regions, and as <a1_0>Cassette<a1_0/> (カセット, Kasetto?) in Japan and parts of Latin America. While the SNES can address 128 Mbit,[f] only <a2_0>117.75 Mbit<a2_0/> are actually available for cartridge use. A fairly normal mapping could easily address up to 95 Mbit of ROM data (48 Mbit at FastROM speed) with 8 Mbit of battery-backed RAM. However, most available memory access controllers only support <b8_0>mappings of up to 32 Mbit<b8_0/>. The largest games released (<a3_0>Tales of Phantasia and Star Ocean<a3_0/>) contain 48 Mbit of ROM data, while the smallest games contain only <a4_0><b7_0><b9_0>2 Mbit<b9_0/><b7_0/><a4_0/>.
